Blue Shift é uma expansão originalmente pensada como um conteúdo bônus para marcar o lançamento de HL para o Dreamcast, mas com a mudança de planos da SEGA em relação ao seu console, o jogo foi convertido para o lançamento no PC.

Desta vez, o protagonista é Barney Calhoun, um dos seguranças que trabalhavam no complexo no dia do acidente com os materiais anômalos, e após a ressonância em cascata, ele se junta a um pequeno grupo de cientistas para tentarem escapar da instalação.

Desde o inicio daquele dia, já se percebia que havia algo de errado, pois varias eram as falhas de sistema que estavam ocorrendo por toda Black Mesa. Uma destas falhas inclusive foi o emperramento da porta da entrada de serviço por onde entravam os seguranças, e por isso e que pode ser visto um guarda esmurrando a porta no inicio do HL original.

O jogo em si mantém a mesma dinâmica dos anteriores, mas apresenta uma campanha bem menor, além de menos variedade de armas e sem os novos alienígenas introduzidos em HL: Opposing Force.

De novidade mesmo, pode se dizer que Blue Shift trouxe uma certa melhora gráfica em relação aos outros, mas que mesmo assim, não vai fazer muita diferença nos dias de hoje, pois já está novamente ultrapassada rs!

Enfim, Blue Shift e uma expansão curta e sem grandes novidades, porém apresenta um gameplay sólido nos mesmos padrões do jogo original, sendo uma visão diferenciada dos eventos ocorridos em Black Mesa. Apesar de suas restrições, continua sendo fortemente recomendado. EXCELENTE (9/10).

A great extension of the Half-Life series!

Blue Shift is another continuation of the original Half Life games. This time you assume the role of security guard Barney Calhoun, during the events of the original game. Just like the original game and Opposing Force, your main objective is to survive by assisting fellow Black Mesa Employees, using any weapon or tool to your advantage and by using your wits. Blue shift does just that.

Gameplay wise, It's still the engaging Half Life everyone knows and loves. Real Time cutscenes? Check. Aggresive and sophisticated enemies? Check. Reliable friendly NPC's? Check. Clever puzzles and well designed levels? Check. And the epic and intense gunplay that the original had? Yep, it's all here. Graphically, it's just like the previous games. The levels look as varied as ever, and the audio still breaths a great atmosphere into the game. So far, everything that is included in this expansion is good.

But it's the worst installment in the series.

And why, do you ask? Because, unlike it's predecessors, it's really short. Really, really short. And unlike Opposing Force, it didn't really add anything new. OK, maybe the HEV battery pickups have now been replaced by Body armour since you are a security guard instead of a heavily armoured scientist/soldier. But... other than that... that's it. No new guns, no new NPC types, friendly or enemy, no new level obstacles and gimmicks, no nothing. Hell, it even lacks some things from the original Half Life, such as certain weapons and an end boss. With an impressive expansion like Opposing force being released before this, I was honestly expecting to see a lot more, but instead, it feels like a watered down Half Life. It's still nice, but it could've been so much more.

Overall, Half Life: Blue Shift is a fairly decent expansion, although a tad bit underwhelming considering the content it's two predecessors delivered before it. If you enjoyed Half Life or Opposing Force, I'd say you check Blue Shift out. If you never played either of those two, this is not the best place to start. It's way too short and light on content and the other Half Life games deliver so much more. Get those instead, then buy this during a sale.

Blue Shift takes the perspective of security guard Barney Calhoun during the Black Mesa Incident. Barney would go on to become a major character in Half-Life 2 and its episodes, and playing as such an awesome character brings a lot of fun to Blue Shift. There are no new weapons or enemies, but Blue Shift manages to dish out more amazing action while giving a fittingly different feel from Half-Life and OP4. Playing as Barney makes the player feel ill-equipped and often lowly, due to the limited arsenal and wonderfully condescending dialogue from scientists who give you crap for no reason whatsoever. It may be short, but Blue Shift hasn't a single dull moment and remains a triumph of expansion packs with its intuitive puzzle design, interesting story, and pulse pounding action sequences.

[b]Half-Life: Blue Shift[/b]

This is the second expansion pack for one of the best games ever made:[u]Half-Life[/u]. In this expansion pack you play as [u]Barney Calhoun[/u], a Black Mesa security guard. After a scientific mishap causes Black Mesa to be invaded by aliens, Calhoun must fight his way to safety.

[b]Graphics[/b]: The graphics to this game aren't that good. They used to be worse, but they were improved by the High Definiton texture pack.

[b]Story[/b]: Although Blue Shift is a really short game the story isn't bad. It takes place in Black Mesa but some parts of the game are on another planet. Calhoun must help Dr. Rosenberg and his colleagues to escape from Black Mesa.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: The gameplay is really similar to Half-Life.Calhoun battles through the game alone, but is occasionally assisted by friendly NPC's. Some aliens like headcrabs and vortigaunts return from the original game. 

[b]PRO'S[/b]: Gameplay, Music
[b]CON'S[/b]: Really short

This is possibly one of the easiest games to either recommend or not recommend - it is more Half-Life. If you enjoyed Half-Life, you should get this game. If you did not enjoy Half-Life, you should not. If you have not played Half-Life, you should get and play that game first.

Simple as that.

As for the game itself, it's a competent, if rather short, side story to the original Half-Life, following the story of Barney (who returns in Half-Life 2), one of the security guards from the Black Mesa facility. When everything goes to hell...err....Xen, he tries to help the scientists and escape from the facility himself. It's a fun little romp back through Black Mesa, but it is no different mechanically from the original game - it does not add anything, and is missing some of the features of the original game. It's worth a budget price purchase, but is the lesser of the two Half-Life expansions.

Half-Life: Blue Shift.  I wish there was such a thing as a Blue Shift in the real world of work, seeing as a Blue Shift at Black Mesa only lasts 3 hours.  Now Half-Life and Half-Life: Opposing Force are not known for their lengthly storylines but one would come to expect a little more from an expansion to one of the greatest games of all time.

Blue Shift places the player in the shoes of Black Mesa security officer Barney as he attempts to escape the Black Mesa science facility during the events of the original Half-Life; which run in parallel with the Blue Shift storyline.  Unfortunately the very limited script and lack of anything that could be considered an expansion of the original Half-Life experience means you will feel rather unsatisfied by the rather lacklustre ending to what feels like no more than a fan made mod.

The only reason I can recommend for playing Blue Shift is to that you are granted an additional 3 hours of Half-Life gameplay, which can only be a good thing.

This game is a really lazy attempt to cash in on the popularity of Half-Life. The game is disappointingly short, lacks any serious challenge, interesting weapons, or new enemies. The story is also pretty lack luster. You play as Barney, the security guard you see pounding on the door in the intro to Half-Life, who is later used as a side character in Half-Life 2. The G-Man plays no serious role in the game, unlike his direct involvement in the endings of Half-Life, or Opposing Force. The ending (spoiler alert) falls completely flat. Get teleported to a parking lot, then drive away. No enemies, no hurry, no stress, no reward. Huzzah, right? I want to like this game, but I don't. Gearbox and Valve got really lazy. Your money is better spent on Opposing Force, about 10 new guns, about 5 new enemeis, new bosses, a pretty decent story, and an interesting new perspective. Blue Shift offers none of this, and isn't worth your time.
